title: What does Boris Johnson's new Brexit deal mean for Northern Ireland and why is the DUP opposing it?
text:
Boris Johnson has secured some key changes to the controversial Irish backstop, which he previously warned no prime minister could accept.

It has been replaced with a new backstop, or a "protocol," which keeps Northern Ireland aligned with the EU's rules on goods and, to some extent, on customs.

This would mean checks on goods and customs would be carried out in the Irish sea, rather than on the 310-mile long land border.

However, Northern Ireland would charge UK tariffs on goods entering its territory, unless they were headed south to the Republic of Ireland, which is in the EU. In that scenario, an EU tariff would be applied.
description: Boris Johnson has secured some key changes to the controversial Irish backstop, which he previously warned no prime minister could accept.
